name: Wright Brothers National Memorial
description: Wind, sand, and a dream of flight brought Wilbur and Orville Wright to Kitty Hawk, North Carolina where, after four years of scientific experimentation, they achieved the first successful airplane flights on December 17, 1903. With courage and perseverance, these self-taught engineers relied on teamwork and application of the scientific process. What they achieved changed our world forever.
shortDescription: Wind, sand, and a dream of flight brought Wilbur and Orville Wright to Kitty Hawk, North Carolina where, after four years of scientific experimentation, they achieved the first successful airplane fli...

operatingHours.description: These are the times the park grounds and visitor center are open for visitors.

fees.title: Entrance - Per Person
fees.description: Fee is charged per-person, NOT per vehicle. Ages 15 and younger are free of charge.

fees.title: Commercial Entrance - Sedan
fees.description: $25 plus $7 per person.  Sedans have a capacity of 1-6 people.

fees.title: Commercial Entrance - Van
fees.description: A flat fee for all Van/ Small Bus with a seating capacity of 7-16 passengers

fees.title: Commercial Entrance - Mini-bus
fees.description: Fee is charged for any commercial vehicle with a capacity of 16-25 individuals.

fees.title: Commercial Entrance - Motor Coach
fees.description: Fees charged for commercial vehicles with a capacity of over 26 individuals.

fees.title: Entrance - Education/Academic Groups
fees.description: Structured educational visits that serve a curriculum need for a class may apply for a waiver for entrance fees in advance.

climate.weatherDescription: Weather on the Outer Banks varies seasonally and daily. Summers can be very hot and sunny (wear sunscreen and drink water), while winters can be cold and wet. High winds are always a possibility any time of the year. It is not uncommon for a brief winter snow each year. Being on a barrier island, the memorial is susceptible to storm impacts, including hurricanes in the summer and nor'easters in the winter. No matter what time of year you visit, dress for the weather, and be ready for wind!

images.title: First Flight
images.altText: Orville takes to the air in the flyer for the first time as Wilbur assists.
images.caption: Orville takes to the air in the flyer for the first time on December 17, 1903.
images.credit: Wilbur Wright, Orville Wright, and John Daniels

images.title: Busts and Moon
images.altText: Copper busts of the two brothers with the moon visible in the blue sky.
images.caption: Copper busts of Wilbur and Orville Wright stand atop Big Kill Devil Hill.

images.title: First Flight Boulder
images.altText: The large boulder and plaque sit where the Wright brothers first flew in their 1903 flyer.
images.caption: This boulder marks the spot where the Wright brothers first flew in their 1903 flyer.

images.title: Walking Along History
images.altText: Visitors walk along the flight line where Wilbur and Orville Wright flew and landed.
images.caption: Visitors explore the landing spots of the Wright brothers' first flights.

images.title: Wright Brothers Monument
images.altText: View straight up at the monument with the Sun directly behind the stonework.
images.caption: Black-and-white image of the Wright Brothers Monument

images.title: National Aviation Day
images.altText: Two young girls look across the grounds of Wright Brothers National Memorial.
images.caption: Visitors enjoy celebrating aviation where modern aviation was born.

images.title: Journey to the Top
images.altText: Visitors moving along a sidewalk to the top of the hill where the monument stands.
images.caption: Visitors climb Big Kill Devil Hill to visit the Wright Brothers Monument.
